titlestmt.title: Blake's Chaucer: An Original Engraving Copy A : electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi , University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
titlestmt.sponsor: The Library of Congress, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and the University of Rochester

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file approx. 32KB; 6 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 150KB to 840KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; UNC Libraries April 2023
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of a Chaucer Omnibus, a selection of seven works by Blake on the subject of Geoffrey Chaucer.
The Archive has previously published works by Blake that are of a Chaucerian nature; these include five pages in the Notebook, Objects 58, 67, and 119–21, in Manuscripts and Typographic Works, the tempera painting of Sir Jeffery Chaucer and the Nine and Twenty Pilgrims on their Journey to Canterbury, in Drawings and Paintings, and all four states of the engraving of the painting, in Separate Prints and Prints in Series. Both the engraving and painting can also be viewed in a multi-gallery presentation in Archive Exhibitions. The exhibition includes works in the Omnibus that are now also accessible in their genre categories:
Blake’s Chaucer: The Canterbury Pilgrims, 1809, a single page prospectus for the engraving of his painting, which he refers to as a "Fresco Picture."
Blake's Chaucer: An Original Engraving, 1810, an advertisement for and three-page leaflet describing the engraving.
Exhibition of Paintings in Fresco, Poetical and Historical Inventions, 1809, an advertisement for Blake's exhibition with a one-page text on "The Invention of a portable Fresco," dated May 15, 1809 (in pen and ink). The sheet was folded to make an envelope addressed to "Ozias Humphry, Esq. / Sloan Street." Blake had enclosed "a ticket of admission" to his exhibition and a short letter asserting that "Florentine & Venetian Art cannot exist together," claims he expounds upon in the exhibition’s Descriptive Catalogue, which includes Blake's lengthy description of his Chaucer painting.
These works are now available for study in Manuscripts and Typographic Works, as is the Descriptive Catalogue.
Another work in the Archive's digital exhibition on Chaucer now accessible in its genre category of Drawings and Paintings is
The Canterbury Pilgrims: Sketch for the Engraving, 1809, a pencil drawing based on the painting but reducing its size to that of the engraving.
The Omnibus also includes two works in Commercial Book Illustrations:
An engraving after a design by Stothard, dated March 1783, that served as the frontispiece to volume XIII of The Poetical Works of Geoffrey Chaucer in Bell’s Edition [of] the Poets of Great Britain.
The Prologue and Characters of Chaucer's Pilgrims Selected from his Canterbury Tales, which comprises a frontispiece, dated Dec 26, 1811, and a tailpiece. The former reproduces, at a much reduced size, a portion of the left side of the large engraving; the latter is a vignette of Canterbury Cathedral.
Also included in the Omnibus is a
portrait of Chaucer from the series of Eighteen Heads of Poets that Blake painted in watercolor and pen and ink for William Hayley's library, c. 1800-1803, and now in the Manchester Art Gallery. It is the first of the series in the Archive (to be joined by the others in due course) and can be found under Drawings and Paintings.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objdescid.origination: G. Smeeton printer This printed prospectus is a compilation of material from two sources, between which exist several differences. One source is the *Descriptive Catalogue* of 1809, paragraphs 14, 15, and 17; the other is the *Notebook*, pages 117-119 (Bentley, *Writings* volume 2, page 863-864). Bentley notes that the differences between this prospectus and the source texts suggest the printer worked from a manuscript which contained material from both the *Notebook* and the *Descriptive Catalogue* (Bentley, *Writings* volume 2, page 864).

imprint.publisher: William Blake No publisher is recorded on the work. However, given the nature of the document, it is safe to assume this work was published by Blake. Just as Blake circulated flyers advertising his 1809 exhibition and *Descriptive Catalogue*, he probably sent copies of this leaflet to his friends (Bentley, *Writings* volume 2, page 1695).
imprint.pubplace: London No place of publication is recorded on the work. However, Blake lived in London when this work was designed and printed, and the address of the printer is located in London.
imprint.date: 1810 The watermark on Copies B and C indicate that this work was published in 1810; see the note on Watermark below.

objinfo.watermark: none Though no watermark appears on this Copy, the watermark "H WILLMOT / 1810" appears on Copies B and C, establishing an initial terminus for this work.
objinfo.binding: bound in card This work is bound in a card cover with Copy A of *Blake's Chaucer: The Canterbury Pilgrims*.

provenance.name: British Museum
provenance.note: Probably acquired by Anne (Mrs. Alexander) Gilchrist at an unknown time; likely bequeathed by inheritance in 1885 to her son, Herbert H. Gilchrist; sold by H. H. Gilchrist with thirteen other works by Blake and his brother Robert, including Robert Blake's drawing of the *Approach of Doom*, to the British Museum for £150 in June 1894.

desc.objtitle:
Blake's Chaucer: An Original Engraving ,
Object 1 (Bentley 1)

lg.l: Blake's Chaucer:

An Original Engraving by him from his Fresco
Paint- painting

ing painting
of Sir
Jeffery Geoffrey
Chaucer and his Nine and Twenty
Pilgrims setting forth from Southwark on their Journey
to Canterbury.
Three Feet 1 Inch long, and 1 Foot high;
Price Three Guineas.
The time chosen is early morning before sun-rise when the
Jolly Company are just quitting the Tabarde Inn. The
Knight and Squire with the Squires and Yeoman lead the
Procession; then the youthful Abbess, her Nun and three
Priests: her Grey-hounds attend her
"Of small hounds had she, that she fed
With roast flesh, milk and wastel bread."

Next follow the Friar and Monk, then the Tapster, Bentley notes that 'Tapster' is a misprint for 'Tapiser', the former meaning one who draws beer or wine and the latter meaning weaver (*Writings* volume 2, page 864; 1695).
the Pardoner, the Sompnour and the Manciple. After

these "Our Host," who occupies the Center of the
Caval- Cavalcade

cade, Cavalcade
directs them to the Knight as the person who will be
likely to commence their Task of each telling a Tale in their
order. After the Host follow the Shipman, the Haberdasher,
the Dyer, the Franklin, the Physician, the Plowman, the
Lawyer, the Parson, the Merchant, the Wife of Bath, the
Cook, the Oxford Scholar, Chaucer himself, and the Reeve
comes as Chaucer has described:
"And ever he rode hinderest of the rout."
These last are issuing from the Gateway of the Inn.

The Cook and the Wife of Bath are both taking their
morn- morning's

ing's morning's
draught of comfort. Spectators stand at the Gateway
of the Inn, and are composed of an Old Man, a Woman
and Children.
This Inn is yet extant under the name of the Talbot;

and the Landlord, Robert Bristow,
Esq. Esquire
of Broxmore near

Rumsey, has continued a board over the Gateway,
inscri- inscribed

bed inscribed
"This is the Inn from which Sir
Jeffery Geoffrey Chaucer and
his Pilgrims set out for Canterbury."
St. Saint Thomas's Hospital which is situated near to it,
is one of the most amiable features of the Christian Church,

it belonged to the Monastery
efThe word “ef” is likely a printing error for “of”. Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 865n) and Erdman (569) make the correction in their transcription. of
St. Saint
Mary Overies and was
dedicated to Thomas a Becket. The Pilgrims, if sick or

lame, on their Journey to and from his Shrine, were
recei- received

ved received
at this House. Even at this day every friendless wretch
who wants the succour succor of it, is considered as a Pilgrim
travelling traveling through this Journey of Life.
The Landscape is an eastward view of the Country from
the Tabarde Inn in Southwark as it may be supposed to

have appeared in Chaucer's time; interspersed with
Cot- Cottages

tages Cottages
and Villages. The first beams of the sun are seen
above the horrizonhorizon: some Buildings and Spires indicate the
situation of the Great City. The Inn is a Gothic Building

which
Thynne Francis Thynne
in his Glossary says was the Lodging of the
Abbot of Hyde by Winchester. On the Inn is inscribed its
Title, and a proper advantage is taken of this circumstance
to describe the subject of the Picture. The words written
in Gothic Letters over the Gateway of the Inn are as follow:
"The Tarbade Inn by Henry Bailly. The Lodging House

for Pilgrims who Journey to St. Thomas's Shrine at
Canter- Canterbury
buryCanterbury."
Of Chaucer's Characters as described in his Canterbury
Tales, some of the Names are altered by Time, but the

Characters themselves for ever remain unaltered
endThe word “end” is likely a printing error for “and”. Bentley (*Writings* volume 2, page 865n) and Erdman (570) make the correction in their transcription. and
conse- consequently

quently consequently
they are the Physiognomies or
Leneaments Lineaments
of
Universal Human Life beyond which Nature never steps.
The Painter has consequently varied the heads and forms
of his Personages into all Nature's varieties. the Horses he

has varied to accord to their riders, the Costume is
cor- correct

rect correct
according to authentic Monuments.
Subscriptions received at No. 28, Corner of Broad
Street, Golden Square.

textfoot.l: G. Smeeton, Printer, 17, St. Martin's Lane, London.
